p: Emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases are major burden to global public health systems ( Mehand et al., 2018). Many of them are vector-borne infectious diseases that affect a large population in the tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Africa, Latin America, and Southeast Asia), and cause higher morbidity and mortality in low-income countries than developed countries ( Savic et al., 2014). Several recent outbreaks of vector-borne infectious diseases are caused by viruses, such as DENV, Zika virus, and yellow fever virus ( Weaver et al., 2018). Development of point-of-care tests (POCT) for these viruses plays a crucial role in the prevention and control of vector-borne infectious diseases in resource-poor countries/regions ( Kozel and Burnham-Marusich, 2017). In this study, we developed a mismatch-tolerant LAMP method and demonstrated its practical use by improving the sensitivity and specificity of a previous established RT-LAMP assay for the detection of all four DENV serotypes.
